wiki_catalogs.name: Project Overview
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive content for this section focused on the overall test automation framework for OpenCart. Explain its purpose as a browser-based end-to-end testing solution using Python, Selenium, and Pytest. Describe the architectural intent of validating both frontend user workflows and backend administrative functions. Highlight key features such as Page Object Model implementation, cross-browser support, Docker integration, and dual test styles (procedural and POM-based). Discuss the target audience including QA engineers, automation developers, and DevOps engineers. Provide context on how this framework fits into CI/CD pipelines and regression testing workflows. Include high-level diagrams showing test execution flow from pytest invocation through page interactions to OpenCart UI. Use examples from actual test files to illustrate scope and capabilities.

wiki_catalogs.name: Main Page
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the MainPage class that represents the OpenCart homepage. Explain its role in the Page Object Model, including key methods such as navigating to the login or register page, accessing the shopping cart, and interacting with top-menu elements. Document the locator strategies used (e.g., CSS selectors for navigation links) and how inheritance from BasePage enables reliable element interaction. Use examples from test_main_page_po.py to demonstrate how tests interact with the main page. Include guidance on extending the MainPage for custom themes or dynamic banners, and address common issues like element visibility delays and resolution-specific layout changes.

wiki_catalogs.name: Admin Login
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the AdminLoginPage component responsible for authenticating into the OpenCart admin backend. Explain the implementation of login form interaction, including element locators for username, password, and submit button. Document the use of BasePage inheritance for common actions like typing and clicking. Illustrate how credentials are passed via environment variables or CLI arguments through conftest.py fixtures. Use test_admin_login_po.py as a reference to demonstrate POM-based login validation and error handling (e.g., invalid credentials). Include best practices for writing reliable login tests, such as handling CSRF tokens, dynamic redirects, and session persistence. Address common issues like stale elements or timing issues during redirection post-login.

wiki_catalogs.name: Getting Started
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive content for this section focused on initial setup and execution of the test framework. Provide step-by-step instructions for installing Python dependencies (Selenium, Pytest), configuring Docker environment using docker-compose.yml, and verifying installation. Include commands for running basic test suites with default settings. Explain how conftest.py initializes the browser driver and how pytest.ini configures test discovery and output. Demonstrate running the first test with and without Docker. Address common setup pitfalls such as missing drivers, version incompatibilities, and network configuration issues. Provide troubleshooting tips for initial execution failures and expected output samples.

wiki_catalogs.name: Category Page
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the CategoryPage class responsible for product category browsing functionality. Document its methods for loading category listings, verifying product grid rendering, and navigating to individual product pages. Explain the use of dynamic locators for category-specific elements and how waits are integrated for AJAX-loaded content. Reference actual usage in test_catalog_po.py to illustrate test interactions. Include implementation details on handling pagination and filtering if present, and provide best practices for updating locators when OpenCart templates change. Address potential issues like stale element references and timeout handling during slow loads.

wiki_catalogs.name: Admin Dashboard
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the AdminDashboardPage that represents the post-login landing interface in OpenCart's admin panel. Document key elements such as navigation menus, statistics widgets, and quick access links. Explain how the page verifies successful authentication by checking the presence of dashboard-specific elements. Describe interactions like navigating between admin sections (e.g., Catalog, Sales, Extensions) using sidebar links. Highlight the use of explicit waits from utils/waits.py to handle dynamic content loading. Provide examples from test_admin_login_po.py showing dashboard validation after login. Include guidance on asserting dashboard state, handling permission-based UI variations, and integrating dashboard checks into broader test workflows.

wiki_catalogs.name: Configuration Guide
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive content for this section focused on the configuration mechanisms within the test framework. Detail all CLI arguments supported via conftest.py including --browser, --base-url, --admin-path, and --headless. Explain how environment variables are used to securely pass admin credentials. Document the precedence between command-line options and environment variables. Provide examples of typical configuration combinations for different test environments (local, staging, CI). Include guidance on customizing timeouts, window sizes, and implicit waits. Illustrate with real code examples how configuration values are injected into test sessions through pytest fixtures.

wiki_catalogs.name: Product Page
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the ProductPage class that handles product detail views and cart interactions. Cover methods for retrieving product information (name, price), selecting options (quantity, variants), and adding items to the cart. Explain the implementation of cart state validation and success message detection. Use test cases from test_product_page_po.py to demonstrate end-to-end usage. Detail the locator strategy for dynamic product options and how BasePage's smart scrolling ensures element visibility. Provide guidance on extending the class for complex product types and troubleshooting common failures like missing add-to-cart buttons or incorrect pricing.

wiki_catalogs.name: Admin Product Management
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the AdminProductsPage used to manage product inventory in OpenCart's admin interface. Cover core operations: adding new products (filling name, model, price, SEO fields), deleting existing products via bulk actions, and editing product details. Document the use of dynamic selectors for table rows, checkboxes, and action buttons. Explain how the page interacts with modals and confirmation dialogs. Use test_admin_products_po.py to illustrate a full workflow: login → navigate to products → add product → validate success message → delete product. Highlight integration with WebDriverWait and custom wait utilities for handling AJAX-driven updates. Provide best practices for data isolation, cleanup, and handling of duplicate product constraints.

wiki_catalogs.name: Page Object Model Architecture
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create architectural documentation for the Page Object Model implementation. Describe the design principles behind inheriting all page classes from BasePage and how this promotes code reuse and maintainability. Explain the core methods implemented in base.py such as click(), type(), wait_visible(), and their intelligent scrolling behavior. Detail how locators are defined as class attributes and used in page methods. Illustrate with concrete examples from main_page.py and register_page.py how page actions encapsulate complex user interactions. Discuss the benefits of this pattern for test stability and readability. Include diagrams showing the inheritance hierarchy and method delegation flow.

wiki_catalogs.name: Login Page
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the LoginPage class used for user authentication on the OpenCart frontend. Document its methods for entering credentials, submitting the login form, and detecting login errors. Explain how the page handles success redirection and session establishment. Use examples from test_main_page_po.py or related procedural tests to show real-world usage. Describe the locator patterns for email and password fields, and how synchronization with page reloads is managed via explicit waits. Include tips for handling multi-factor authentication extensions and common pitfalls like cached credentials interfering with test isolation.

wiki_catalogs.name: Core Modules Reference
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive content for this section focused on the foundational modules that power the test framework. For conftest.py, document all pytest fixtures including browser, base_url, wait, and admin_creds, explaining their scope, lifecycle, and dependency chain. For utils/waits.py, detail the custom wait conditions implemented and how they improve reliability over standard Selenium waits. For docker-compose.yml, explain the service definitions, container networking, and how it enables isolated, reproducible test environments. Provide usage examples showing how tests consume these modules. Address performance implications and best practices for extending each component.

wiki_catalogs.name: Register Page
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the RegisterPage class that manages new user account creation. Explain its methods for filling personal information, password fields, and marketing consent checkboxes. Highlight the handling of dynamic elements such as the agreement checkbox that appears conditionally. Use test_register_po.py to demonstrate test flows including valid registration and error case validation (e.g., duplicate email). Document the use of BasePage methods for form submission and success confirmation. Provide best practices for generating test data and managing test user lifecycle, along with troubleshooting tips for CAPTCHA interference or JavaScript-driven form validation.

wiki_catalogs.name: Frontend Testing
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for frontend testing capabilities of the framework. Cover each user-facing page object: MainPage for homepage interactions, CategoryPage for browsing product categories, ProductPage for product details and cart actions, LoginPage for user authentication, and RegisterPage for account creation with dynamic form handling. Explain the CurrencyDropdown component as a reusable UI element. For each, document key methods, locator strategies, and interaction patterns. Use actual test cases from test_main_page_po.py and test_register_po.py to demonstrate usage. Include guidance on extending these pages for new OpenCart themes or customizations.

wiki_catalogs.name: Currency Dropdown Component
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the CurrencyDropdown component, a reusable UI element for switching currencies on the OpenCart storefront. Explain its encapsulation as a separate class under components/ and how it integrates with MainPage or other page objects. Document methods for opening the dropdown, selecting a currency by name, and verifying the active currency display. Use test_currency_po.py to illustrate interaction patterns and assertion logic. Describe the locator strategy for dropdown options and how dynamic content updates are synchronized. Include guidance on reusing this component in new page objects and adapting it for stores with custom currency selectors or multi-language considerations.

wiki_catalogs.name: Admin Testing
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for administrative interface testing. Cover AdminLoginPage for authentication into the OpenCart backend, AdminDashboardPage for post-login navigation and status verification, and AdminProductsPage for product management operations (add, delete, edit). Document the specialized locators and workflows unique to the admin panel. Explain how admin credentials are securely handled via environment variables. Use test_admin_products_po.py as a reference to demonstrate complex workflows involving multiple page transitions. Provide best practices for creating robust admin tests that handle dynamic content and permission variations.

wiki_catalogs.name: Test Writing Guide
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive content focused on writing effective tests using this framework. Contrast procedural tests (like test_main_page.py) that use direct Selenium calls with POM-based tests (like test_product_page_po.py) that leverage page objects. Explain when to use each approach and their respective trade-offs. Demonstrate parameterized testing, fixture usage, and assertion patterns using real examples. Show how to write multi-step scenario tests using test_scenarios.py as reference. Include guidance on test organization, naming conventions, and dependency management. Provide templates for new test files and anti-patterns to avoid.

wiki_catalogs.name: Best Practices
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive content focused on recommended practices for maintaining and extending this test automation framework. Cover locator strategy selection (prioritizing CSS selectors and data attributes over XPath), proper use of explicit waits from utils/waits.py, and error handling patterns. Discuss page object design principles such as single responsibility, method cohesion, and avoiding test logic in page classes. Use register_page.py as an example of handling complex forms with conditional elements. Address performance optimization through efficient element location and browser reuse. Include debugging techniques using browser screenshots and logging. Provide guidelines for test flakiness reduction and reliable test design.

wiki_catalogs.name: CI/CD Integration
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create architectural documentation for integrating the test framework into CI/CD pipelines. Explain how docker-compose.yml enables consistent execution across different environments including CI runners. Detail how pytest.ini controls test output format for reporting tools. Describe strategies for parallel test execution, test result aggregation, and failure notifications. Provide sample pipeline configurations for popular CI systems (GitHub Actions, GitLab CI, Jenkins) showing containerized test execution. Address artifact collection (screenshots, logs, result.json) and retention policies. Include performance considerations for running headless browsers in containers and resource allocation guidelines.

wiki_catalogs.name: Troubleshooting
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content focused on diagnosing and resolving common issues in test execution. Cover browser driver initialization failures, element not found exceptions, timeout errors, and synchronization problems. Explain how to interpret error messages from Selenium and pytest. Provide solutions for common scenarios such as elements not clickable due to overlay, stale element references, and unexpected alert dialogs. Use the smart scrolling mechanism in base.py and custom waits in waits.py as tools for resolving visibility issues. Include debugging workflow recommendations: enabling verbose logging, taking screenshots on failure, and using browser developer tools in non-headless mode.

wiki_catalogs.name: Appendix
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive content for supplementary information. Document OpenCart version compatibility based on the configuration files in opencart_data. List known limitations of the test framework such as unsupported OpenCart extensions, browser-specific quirks, or missing admin features. Provide contribution guidelines covering code style, test coverage expectations, and pull request workflow. Include references to external documentation (OpenCart API, Selenium WebDriver, Pytest) and tooling. Address data privacy considerations when handling credentials and test artifacts. Provide upgrade paths for future OpenCart versions.

wiki_overview.content:
<blog>
# Comprehensive Project Analysis

## 1. Project Introduction

### Purpose Statement
This project is an automated testing framework designed for the OpenCart e-commerce platform. It focuses on validating both the frontend user experience and backend administrative functionality through browser automation.

### Core Goals and Objectives
- Automate end-to-end testing of OpenCart's core features including user registration, product browsing, and login flows
- Provide reusable page objects for consistent interaction with UI elements
- Support cross-browser testing (Chrome, Firefox, Safari) with configurable options
- Enable seamless integration into CI/CD pipelines using Docker and pytest

### Target Audience
The primary users of this project are QA engineers, automation developers, and DevOps teams responsible for ensuring the stability and reliability of OpenCart deployments.

---

## 2. Technical Architecture

### Component Breakdown
The project follows a Page Object Model (POM) design pattern, separating test logic from page-specific implementations. Key components include:
- **Base Page**: Foundational class providing common browser interactions
- **Page Modules**: Individual classes representing specific pages (login, product, category, etc.)
- **Test Cases**: Pytest-based test files validating functionality
- **Configuration**: Centralized setup via `conftest.py` and CLI parameters

### Design Patterns
- **Page Object Model (POM)**: Encapsulates UI element locators and actions within dedicated classes
- **Fixture Pattern**: Uses pytest fixtures for browser management and configuration
- **Inheritance**: Pages extend `BasePage` to inherit common methods like `click()` and `type()`

### System Relationships
```mermaid
flowchart TD
    A[Tests] --> B[Page Objects]
    B --> C[BasePage]
    A --> D[conftest.py]
    D --> E[Browser Driver]
    C --> E
    D --> F[Configuration]
    A --> F
```

### Data Flow
```mermaid
flowchart TD
    Config[CLI/Environment Config] --> conftest
    conftest --> Browser[WebDriver Instance]
    Test[Test Execution] --> conftest
    Test --> Pages[Page Objects]
    Pages --> BasePage
    BasePage --> Browser
    Browser --> UI[OpenCart Web Interface]
```

---

## 3. Key Implementation

### Main Entry Points
- Test execution starts via pytest commands that leverage `conftest.py` for environment setup
- Browser initialization and configuration handled through pytest fixtures

### Core Modules
- `pages/base.py`: Base class for all page objects with shared interaction methods
- `pages/admin/*`: Admin-specific page implementations
- `pages/*.py`: Frontend page representations (main, product, category, register)

### Configuration Approach
Uses pytest's plugin system with command-line arguments and environment variables for flexibility:
- Browser selection (`--browser`)
- Base URL customization (`--base-url`)
- Admin credentials via environment variables
- Headless mode support

### External Dependencies
- **Selenium WebDriver**: For browser automation
- **Pytest**: Test runner and framework
- **Docker**: Environment orchestration via `docker-compose.yml`

### Integration Points
- Integrates with OpenCart's admin and public interfaces
- Supports environment variable injection for credentials
- Compatible with CI/CD systems through Docker and standard test output

### Component Relationships
```mermaid
graph LR
    conftest[conftest.py] --> browser[Browser Driver]
    conftest --> config[Configuration]
    BasePage[base.py] --> Selenium[Selenium]
    LoginPage[login_page.py] --> BasePage
    AdminLogin[admin_login_page.py] --> BasePage
    RegisterPage[register_page.py] --> BasePage
    TestLogin[test_admin_login.py] --> AdminLogin
    TestRegister[test_register_page.py] --> RegisterPage
    TestLogin --> conftest
    TestRegister --> conftest
```

---

## 4. Key Features

### Functionality Overview
- Admin authentication testing
- User registration validation
- Product and category navigation
- Currency dropdown interaction
- Cross-browser compatibility

### Implementation Highlights
- Smart click handling with scroll-and-execute fallback
- Dynamic password field detection in registration
- Robust agreement checkbox handling
- Flexible URL construction across pages
- Comprehensive error reporting in registration flow

### Feature Architecture
```mermaid
stateDiagram-v2
    [*] --> Setup
    Setup --> BrowserInit: pytest.fixture
    BrowserInit --> TestExecution
    TestExecution --> LoginPage
    LoginPage --> AdminDashboard: Successful Login
    LoginPage --> LoginPage: Failed Login
    TestExecution --> RegisterPage
    RegisterPage --> Success: Account Created
    RegisterPage --> Errors: Validation Messages
    Success --> [*]
    Errors --> [*]
    AdminDashboard --> Logout
    Logout --> LoginPage
```

Sources:
- [conftest.py](/Users/tanuuu/otus_02_2025/conftest.py#L0-L80)
- [base.py](/Users/tanuuu/otus_02_2025/pages/base.py#L0-L35)
- [login_page.py](/Users/tanuuu/otus_02_2025/pages/login_page.py#L0-L15)
- [admin_login_page.py](/Users/tanuuu/otus_02_2025/pages/admin/admin_login_page.py#L0-L25)
- [admin_dashboard_page.py](/Users/tanuuu/otus_02_2025/pages/admin/admin_dashboard_page.py#L0-L12)
- [main_page.py](/Users/tanuuu/otus_02_2025/pages/main_page.py#L0-L12)
- [product_page.py](/Users/tanuuu/otus_02_2025/pages/product_page.py#L0-L13)
- [category_page.py](/Users/tanuuu/otus_02_2025/pages/category_page.py#L0-L14)
- [register_page.py](/Users/tanuuu/otus_02_2025/pages/register_page.py#L0-L99)
</blog>
